column4: hey guys, I have finished the partition set-up and changed the to-be linux partition to ext3, but I just got a dialog saying that one partition should be a swap... yes or no?
what does swap do?
it wasn't on my system before?
but...
when I make the linux partition swap, it complains about the root file system
and when I make it ext3 it complains about swap
how much does it hinder my system? I have 2gbs of ram
ddram*
not once have I gone over 75% usage of my ram
i only have 1GB and i rarely need swap
as a general rule, you should have double the memory (including ram and swap) as you are ever likely to use
that's probably a windows partition... possibly windows 98 or ME
with 2GB ram, it probably doesn't matter. just be aware that if you ever run out, an application will be killed at random
yes
if you have used up all your free space you may need to change the partitioning scheme (ie delete the linux partition and make two smaller ones)
and of course, you should have a full backup of all your data before doing *any* partitioning with any OS :)
swap - not bootable
doesn't matter
the only difference between logical and primary is that you can only have a max of four primary partitions. if you make one of those logical you can have more
sadly yes, once the partition table is written it's mostly wait and see
there are several thousand
you will have to choose what you want to learn
